thread.title: City News: Moss Bros, Wolseley, Sports Direct, Boohoo
thread.title_full: City News: Moss Bros, Wolseley, Sports Direct, Boohoo

title: City News: Moss Bros, Wolseley, Sports Direct, Boohoo
text:
GETTY Moss Bros suit up for testing the overseas markets E-commerce sales jumped by 59 per cent and now represent 10 per cent of group revenue. Moss could also boost its UK presence by adding about 15 new stores to its existing 125 outlets. Heating trade has cool period 
SHARES in plumbing and heating supplies giant Wolseley dropped 12 per cent yesterday as it flagged tough trading conditions in Britain and the US. 
The FTSE 100 group’s trading profit from ongoing businesses jumped 11.4 per cent to £857million on 10.1 per cent higher revenue of £13.3billion in the year to 31 July. Chief executive Ian Meakins hailed a “great performance” by its Ferguson business in the US. 
But he warned: “Industrial markets in North America were challenging in the fourth quarter and we expect this to continue. 
“The heating market in the UK is expected to remain very competitive with little growth.” Shares were down 523p to 3656p. 
Heating business has cooled down Sports firm swoops on deal 
MIKE Ashley is poised to gatecrash the sale of replica football strip retailer Kitbag. 
Retail tycoon Ashley’s Sports Direct business has bought a 19 per cent stake worth about £30million in Kitbag’s parent company, home shopping group Findel. 
He made his move as Findel announced it had agreed terms subject to contract for the sale of Kitbag to a third party, not Sports Direct. GETTY Sports Direct have bought the shopping group Findel 
The business could be worth about £20million. The potential buyer is thought to be an overseas group. 
Ashley was believed to be interested in Kitbag last year but Findel decided against offloading.
